entry.title: Sursock bronze (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Sursock bronze (pictured) was discovered in a damaged state with hacked parts, possibly after being vandalized by early Christian iconoclasts?

entry.title: If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that, according to a 2025 book about artificial superintelligence, If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies?

entry.title: Memoirs and Adventures of a Man of Quality (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a Dutch publisher pirated the first four volumes of Memoirs and Adventures of a Man of Quality, then hired the author to write more?

entry.title: King Owodo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that King Owodo, the last Ogiso of Igodomigodo, was deposed after killing a pregnant widow, an act punishable by deposition under the kingdom's law?

entry.title: Bill Gutteron (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that NFL player Bill Gutteron estimated that he helped over 50,000 people learn how to swim?

entry.title: an early Chinese women's magazine (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that an early Chinese women's magazine ran afoul of a government ministry due to its sexual content and nudity?

entry.title: the first bank of the Republic of Lithuania (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the first bank of the Republic of Lithuania was bankrupt after nine years of operation?

entry.title: Fernald Feed Materials Production Center (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Fernald Feed Materials Production Center produced uranium for nuclear weapons between 1951 and 1989?

entry.title: Hilaire Belloc and G. K. Chesterton (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Hilaire Belloc and G. K. Chesterton's first collaboration sold only thirty-five copies?

entry.title: Destination of the Month (Wikivoyage recommendations)
entry.content:
Destination of the Month

San Carlos de Bariloche

The Argentine adventure capital offers great opportunities for skiing, sightseeing, water sports, trekking and climbing amidst the amazing mountainous landscapes of Argentine Patagonia.

entry.title: Off the Beaten Path (Wikivoyage recommendations)
entry.content:
Off the Beaten Path

Sekigahara

This quaint mountain town and battlefield, where Tokugawa won control of Japan, gives visitors firsthand insight into feudal Japanese warfare.

entry.title: Featured Travel Topic (Wikivoyage recommendations)
entry.content:
Featured Travel Topic

Driving in China

China isn't one of the countries that foreigners commonly explore by driving themselves. If you'd still like to, the first step would be getting a local driving licence.
